top_comment.author: Luke and Hannah

comments.text:
I will tell you, it won't last forever, trust me. I know it seems like 
things will never change, but you're only 12. When I was your age I had a 
horrific acne problem, really dry skin on the rest of my body, glasses, and 
braces. I played sports, but I was also a huge dork. I was a tomboy, so I 
didn't really get along with most of the girls in my class, and none of the 
guys were interested in me. I am an introvert, and at the time, I was also 
super shy. My 6th grade year was the worst year of my life. My parents were 
fighting and separated and all of my best friends went to a different 
school. I didn't really have any friends and felt alone ALL the TIME. I had 
no one to talk to, no one that understood me or liked me just for myself. 
It was so bad that I seriously thought about killing myself several times. 
Then, I had some people come into my life who reminded me that I was worth 
something. They showed me that it was ok to just be myself. I guess I'm 
telling you all this just to give you hope. You still have a full life 
ahead of you with so many possibilities. But, you have to learn how to be 
ok with yourself and who you are. Right now, don't worry about what your 
peers think about you. Kids at your age are so shallow. Just focus on being 
happy with who you are.

Remember, you are not worthless. You are unique. One of a kind. If the 
world lost you, we would be losing a part of it that we can never get back, 
a part that can never be replaced. You have a special purpose in life, so 
focus on figuring out what that is right now. I figured out that my purpose 
in life is to teach and help students, so now I'm a teacher who is almost 
done with a Masters degree. There are times when I still struggle with 
depression. There are times when I still struggle with insecurity. There 
are times when I still feel like a failure. But, all of that goes away in 
the moments when I am fulfilling my purpose and can see the difference I've 
made in other peoples' lives.
comments.author: soccerchamp0511

comments.text:
I'm large, as a kid I was the school pick on. I was the kid everyone wanted 
to use as the butt of their jokes, the kid everyone wanted to harass to the 
point that he questioned if life was worth it, what was sanity and what was 
insanity. Sure they didn't notice it, but slowly and slowly I started 
feeling worse. I use to make myself throw up at school at times just to get 
away from all the hate and the harassment. I started getting headaches 
severely when I was in middle school, and found out I have issues with my 
heart. 

This went on until I was in 8th grade. In that time span, elementary to 
8th, I wanted to attempt suicide 3 times. The first time, when I tell my 
story to people, they don't believe me. I was 12. 12 years old and wanted 
to die. To this day, I still battle depression. To this day, I still battle 
a personality disorder. To this day, I have trust issues. To this day, I 
find it hard to love- to think that someone who tells me they love me means 
it.

BUT!- To this day I have opened my eyes that the world, despite how much we 
fuck it up, is beautiful. To this day, I've realized that all this drama 
and heartaches and sleepless nights are just a temporary thing. Life WILL 
get better. Some days will be better than others, vice versa. Hang in there 
and you WILL make it through. Suicide seems like a solution, but to what? 
Suicide is a long term solution to short term problems. One day people will 
see you for YOU. Not based off appearance. Based on YOU as a human being. 
Because outer beauty? Fuck outer beauty. Fuck trying to fit in, because 
being yourself? Being who YOU want to be? Standing up and being 
YOURSELF? That's one of the most beautiful things human nature is capable 
of.
comments.author: Aaron Galloway

comments.text:
Dear Ms.Hannah,
If anyone calls you a mistake again, talk about chocolate chip cookies, 
popsicles, penicillin, X-rays, potato chips and coca-cola. They're ALL 
mistakes.
Tell them they're boxed wine and you're champagne.
Tell them they're nuclear bombs and you're a firework.
Tell them they're the lethal injection and you're a pacemaker.
(pacemakers, fireworks and champagne were all accidents)
Tell them mistakes can be AWESOME!
And if nothing else helps, here is something magical I discovered.
High-school *ends*.
Seriously, might not sound like much but when you're off in collage or 
wherever studying something you love and being awesome at it, you'll meet 
other awesome people and soon you'll have such an cool group around you 
that those bullies can call you all the names they want but they'll just 
slide right off, like water from plastic (also an accident).
Take it from someone who was in your shoes, it gets better.
Every name you get called is just someone stabbing you with their own 
insecurity.
It's someone so shallow they think "ugly" is the worst someone can be, when 
cruel, malicious and hateful are far worse.
When they call you 'weird' it's because they don't know they should value 
uniqueness, it's because they don't value special. When you get out of 
high-school suddenly everybody is desperate to be unique, or different or 
stand-out. All you are, my dear, if ahead of the rest of them.
I hope your school life improves but if it doesn't just wait.
The storm will pass, clouds will clear and you'll stand in the sunshine.
Just wait.
comments.author: Peebles Pebbles

top_comment.text:
I think I should share my story. In grade school I was the one guy who had 
no friends, at lunch on the floor, BUT wasn't bullied. Then in high 
school (third week of grade 9) I was punched on the bus for trying to talk 
to my friend. I stupidly punched back and now I am ridiculed. Embarrassed. 
And I'm still ridiculed, even after 4 months of staying quiet. Staying low, 
being nice to everyone. It does work after everyone forgets or someone does 
something has done something else that's horrible. I'm not on drugs, and 
don't drink. I'm a good kid but other kids don't care. They see one mistake 
and take you as some freak and don't care what you really are. Even my 
friends started to stay away so I wouldn't ruin their reputation. There's 
no way for me to permanently fix this, but then I found this video. This 
man changed it. When someone starts to bully me I just put in my headphones 
and listen to this. It saved me. Healed me. I guess the point of this is, 
when you do something wrong and you start to be harassed, just leave it. 
And if someone who doesn't have anything to do with it starts to join in, 
that's when you take action (phrasing). Get help! No matter what they do 
they have probably made worse life choices than you ever will! Nowadays the 
kid who I thought would pick on me the most stuck up for me because I kept 
my  nose clean. He actually apologized for his friends. People do change, 
and it is hard, but after 2 months, it gets better. People do change! Just 
remember to take action, before loosing control. Sorry if I send some mixed 
messages.﻿

comments.text:
+TheIlikecookies123 Just so you know:

Depression generally is linked to low levels of the neurotransmitter 
serotonin. Effectively at the ends of neurones where the transmission 
passes from one (pre synaptic) neurone to another (post synaptic) neurone, 
the neurotransmitter passes through a gap called the synaptic cleft and 
binds to the other (post synaptic) neurone to continue the transmission. 
What is commonly seen in disorders such as depression is that the serotonin 
does not pass as readily into the post synaptic neurone and is reabsorbed 
into the presynaptic neurone.

This is where medication and antidepressants come in. As it happens the 
contents of an average first aid kit cannot remedy depression but clearly 
the implication was medication cannot help. Well in come SSRIs. Selective 
Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors form a barrier as such over the pre synaptic 
neurone that ‘inhibits’ the reuptake of the serotonin into the neurone 
meaning that it can pass more readily into the post synaptic neurone to 
continue the transmission.So since the implication was that medication 
cannot help you. As it happens, it can help. 

To quote the NHS:

“It would be too simplistic to say that depression and related mental 
health conditions are caused by low serotonin levels, but a rise in 
serotonin levels can improve symptoms and make people more responsive to 
other types of treatment“ 

To all those who want to give more detail to the post I just want to make 
it clear that I do know the process in more detail than this however for 
the sake of keeping the post as simple and short as possible I only want to 
include relevant information for the process. No need to mention vesicles 
ect. because it doesn't affect the fact that the neurotransmitters do cross 
the synapse.

rational.
And in essence, this practice of virtue, IS happiness.

+Mark N Well written, Mark. With regards to examples of those who surpassed 
it, I'd like to point to King George VI and Winston Churchill, both of whom 
had speech impediments, yet become known globally for their speeches to the 
people.

What frustrates me is how little such sentiments come out on TV. Don't get 
me wrong, every show, especially children's shows, has at least one episode 
about being true to yourself. Some even go into the problem of bullying. 
The problem is that so many of them delve into the subject so superficially 
that they prove useless to those of us who end up dealing with it. This is 
quite problematic, given that these shows are often the first time we're 
exposed to the topic.

That's why I'm working on writing a show I hope to get made, adapted from a 
work that actually addresses it openly and honestly, while still managing 
to be exciting and fun.

comments.text:
+EditDeath
I have a number of self conscious manifestations as well as manifestations 
of dyslexia.  The first step to acknowledge strength is recognizing 
weakness in clarity with out elements of self persecuting judgement.   This 
can be exasperated by those who only seek to exploit and demean the 
weaknesses of others for their abyss of insecurity, which is a black hole 
of dysfunction that can be satiated for a moment but will never heal or 
fill with atrocious mean spirited predatory behavior.   The reality is they 
are indeed wrong, but focusing on our own weaknesses in a derogatory way 
can tend to make an individual overly self scrutinizing and resentful of 
the wounds predators seek out and exasperate like piranhas in socials 
waters of herd acceptance.  The blessing is that many who are deemed 
outcasts break from the herd, and with clarity from being distanced from 
it, can see the totally folly of the social mindsets around us.  These end 
up being the estuaries of the artists, poets, philosophers, and visionaries 
detached from main stream delusions.  Some of the greatest minds though out 
the annals of history, were indeed these social outcasts, brave enough to 
accept the unusual blessed gifts they were given and stand boldly in the 
face of any audacious, ignorant, and short sighted social norms.  The 
manifestations of dysfunction does not have a face, but indeed it is a 
spirit to lift one self up at the cost of deprecating another.  This is a 
manifestation I have coined the interpersonal teeter totter.  For the 
severly insecure, life is something you live in perpetual competition, even 
with the ones you call friends and family.  It is indeed a sickness  of the 
spirit, and the vicious teeter totter can live in lesser and greater 
degrees in us all.  Knowing it can, is the first step to paying attention 
for this spirit to grow in any, even ourselves.  Kindness, compassion, and 
cooperation are the paths to beneficial involvement, and society seems void 
of such spirits and when they see those spirits start to emerge in others, 
they desire to rape it out of existence with acts of violence, either in 
words or action.  Fighting the good fight, and knowing our own weaknesses 
is a step to strength the herd will find frightening as their actions just 
become mute to our spiritual eyes and ears.   Much like entering a smoke 
polluted room, the affects of grotesque negativity will cause even the 
strongest to become subject to the pollutants.  Support and re-energizing 
the power within is a constant necessity in staying as healthy as possible 
in a very smoke filled society.   Much like a proctologist, if we fight 
a-holes all day long, we  are still submerged in the experience of dealing 
with a-holes.  We will start to see the world through crap covered 
glasses.  Time to rest and restore and bathe in visions of positive 
possibilities can do immense healing.   The smoke of experiences past may 
lingering on our clothes for much time to come, but if we bend over to 
smell the flowers, we will smell nothing else.
comments.author: Mark N

top_comment.text:
Oh how long the days have gone where everything wasn't so fucking black and 
white. I find it abhorrent that most people believe "you should never have 
to change for people to like you". Never huh? What about a person who gains 
pleasure from seeing people suffer? Or the person that talks openly about 
his hate for black people? Believe it or not, but some traits DO have to be 
abandoned in order to become accepted. It's like experiencing the death of 
a loved one, believing they're not dead isn't going to bring them back, 
being who you were isn't going to change that, so you might as well let 
them go.

This country has turned into such a kindergarten school; "There's no 
excuse". I've been called plenty of names, been bullied as much as the last 
person. I changed so I wouldn't be bullied. Insanity is doing the same 
thing over and over again expecting shit to change. Being accepted starts 
with YOU. I've changed, abandoned some attitudes that I shouldn't of had, 
and I'm a happier person for it "To This Day". See what I did there? Being 
happy or sad is just a state of mind and isn't a life changer. YOU, and 
only YOU, ultimately control your life, not others.

So while I agree with some of this poem, I do not believe it's something 
that should encourage people to stay who they are. If I didn't change, I 
would still have no friends. Don't be miserable the rest of your life, 
CHANGE YOURSELF.﻿
top_comment.author: Russian “are” Faggots

comments.text:
+Horrible Four You obviously don't understand, can you like take a fucking 
class? I'm talking about people who aren't able to change everything about 
themselves. Yeah they can change themselves, BUT THERE'S ONLY SO MUCH YOU 
CAN CHANGE. You're saying that people who have their own personalities 
should change? I'm not talking about drug addicts I'm talking about people 
who take a look at their own individuality, you're saying that they should 
change? Everything that people want to change about themselves they see the 
change through from other people who reach out to them. Yes I'm anti 
social, but because of the people in my life, I've learned that I want to 
be able to reach out to them more. That's not just a change, it's more like 
a form of growth. Yes, we have bad traits, yes there are things about who 
we are that we should change, But change can really happen if we're able to 
let people be a part of the change that we're trying to make ourselves. 
Because if we didn't have people reaching out to us, how would we know the 
direction we should go? I never denied that people shouldn't change and 
stick to the way they are. What this poem is trying to say is that there 
are things we can and can't change about ourselves. The author of this poem 
isn't encouraging people to not change, in fact, he's encouraging people to 
stand up and more forward to change. But the thing that you misunderstand 
is what his focus is truly on. That is, that everyone deserves to be seen 
as beautiful, and through that beauty brings change. Like I said bro, take 
a look at the video again. Because it doesn't take 100% of your brain to 
know what he's trying to really say.. people are depressed because people 
made them that way, but people can come out of depression by people who are 
able to love that person enough. Like I said before too, you change every 
little thing about yourself. But that still won't help you escape from the 
pain and sorrow people once inflicted upon you.
comments.author: RevvinKevin

comments.text:
+Horrible Four Yes, there are bad traits. But a lot of bad traits come 
straight from genetics and it's not the easiest thing to change how you are 
on a genetic level. And you say that people need to change to avoid 
bullying. To a certain extent, everyone should alter their personality a 
bit to fit the situation based off of location and the people involved. 
But, you're blaming the victims rather than the the perpetrators for the 
latter's crimes.

And this of course is all under the assumption that kids are bullied for 
things they can just change. A physical deformity is not something that can 
be changed without a lot of money for surgeries. A mental deficiency or 
illness is not something people can just change about themselves. One or 
both of your parents being of ill repute is something outside of a kid's 
control. Being poor isn't something that the victim can help or change. Or 
my favorite, people being screwed with because of gender, race, or sexual 
orientation. You know, because you just change that too. These are major 
reasons for bullying that seem to pop up a lot. You are making everything 
black and white. Like every victim can just change everything to avoid 
being labelled as an outcast.

I will submit that there are certain things that can be changed. But those 
are behaviors and not genetics or social class giving you a middle finger. 
While one's DNA structure will likely encourage certain behaviors or 
quirks, most people have the self control to not do things that will get 
them fucked with. Like screaming about unicorns in public, or putting porn 
on your school computer. Even then, subconscious thought is a powerful 
thing that can supersede conscious thought.

And your examples of drug addicts and anti-social individuals. Those don't 
help your case much. It's not as simple as just changing and quitting drugs 
most of the time. A drug addict's brain convinces them that they need the 
drugs to keep living. Their brain will put them through hell to force them 
to use drugs again. Many through outside help can overcome this; but, it's 
still extremely difficult and wasn't the simple act of just changing on 
their own.

As for anti-social people, you're using the term wrong. If you mean social 
outcasts, then they have become outcasts because of stigmas and bullying 
against them. Usually, for something outside of their control. An 
anti-social person is someone with Anti-Social Personality Disorder. They 
are sociopaths. They don't care about anyone but themselves and would only 
make friends to screw with them for their own amusement. Those are the 
people that need to change, but it is unfortunately impossible for these 
people to ever change and genuinely feel something for another human being.

top_comment.text:
To the girl/boy who 
stays home from school because she/he
is too depressed to get out of bed, 
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
stands in front of the mirror, unable to 
fight the tears as she/he criticizes every inch,
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
can't keep her/his dinner down because 
she/he only lost two pounds,
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
cries on the cold tile of her/his bathroom
floor with a bloody razor in her/his hand,
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
wears a long sleeve shirt in the middle 
of august to hide all her/his scars,
I love you.

To the girl/boy who
pops a handful of pills just to 
feel normal for a while, 
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
drowns her/his feelings in a bottle of booze,
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
watches the one she/he loves fall 
in love with someone else,
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
has a mother that tells her/him 
she/he isn't good enough,
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
locks her/hid bedroom door 
whenever dad's been drinking,
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
won't go home tonight because her 
parents are always fighting, 
I love you.

To the girl/boy who 
feels hopeless and alone, planning 
to take her/his life, 
I love you.

And to you who reads this letter, whoever you may be, wherever your life 
may take you, always remember; someone out there loves you...
(even if it's only me)
﻿

top_comment.text:
Warning: I'm not a troll, I'm not an asshole, I'm a guy with an opinion!

I feel that bullying, whether it be over the web or online is overblown. 
Yes people get bullied, but it's never insurmountable unless they choose to 
view it as such. I was bullied before, but I didn't get depressed or kill 
myself, I chose to fight for myself, kick their asses, and force them to 
stop.

Bullies don't have some obsession with their victims, once a kid causes the 
bullies problems, they move on to other people. If people let it keep 
happening it's their fault for not making the effort to fight back, 
verbally it physically.

And online trolling/cyber bulling is a joke. If assholes online bother you, 
get offline, get off the web or block them.﻿

cruel to me, they said I was ugly and they will never go out with me, I 
started to hate everyone and started to hate God, because it was not fair. 
I was a great student, I had good grades, I was kind to most of the people, 
then because of this my hate for everyone started to grow, I started 
hitting my brothers and started to bully my younger brothers. I was very 
naive and didn't realize that I was doing the same thing that I hated. It 
wasn't until I got older that I started to understand everything.

Do you feel ugly ? Do you really believe that ?, If you don't like that 
school change it, or change classrooms, there is always a solution to the 
problem, the only thing that we have assured in this life is death.

And life can be either horrible or beautiful until we do something. I am 
telling you because I did was able to do it, and I am still struggling with 
stuff, but now I see things from different perspectives and different 
points of view. You will always have someone that likes you, that cares 
about you, but sometimes we are so blinded by the bad stuff that happens to 
us that we don't see what is in front of us.

Just think of this, I am stranger to you, but I care about you, because I 
feel your pain, I went thru the same thing as you.
Now I have a big family and awesome group of friends. I am telling you, you 
are never alone, just open your eyes.

comments.text:
+1í1y ç and norah, I agree with Thetoptoptenner, everything in life depends 
on how you look at it, I had the same issues as you had, I was battling 
depression and anxiety to the point of committing suicide 3 times, went to 
a psychiatrist for 2 years, after going to 2 psychologist that didn't help 
me that much. I was an atheist as well, and now my path is different, the 
pain, the suffering, the anxiety and the depression is caused by ourselves, 
because we take all of those words seriously, we choose to believe those 
words. Its up to you to fight and choose not to take those words seriously, 
because you know yourself, you know what you are and what you are not.

The most important thing is to know yourself, see why its causing you 
problems, why are you choosing pain instead of happiness. For me it was 
very simple and it took me more than 6 years to find the answer.

I was trying to find love from another person, I wanted people to love me. 
But how I was going to find love in another person, if I didn't loved 
myself first, I hated myself, I didn't even want to look at myself in the 
mirror, now I am learning to love myself, to take care of myself and things 
are very different now. I have a lovely wife, 4 kids and my life is going 
great and I thank God for the experience I am going thru right now.

I know that most of you once they see the word God, you will start to 
question this answer, you will choose not to believe because it sounds 
ridiculous in your mind. You are choosing pain, because you are so used to 
feel fear and pain that you don't really want to choose God. You don't need 
a religion to find God, you want a proof that God exists ? look at yourself 
in the mirror, take a very close look at yourself, at your surroundings, 
the universe, how every system and ecosystem works, do you really think all 
of this is just a mere kind of randomness ? all of this its not random, 
random doesn't exist, if you flip a dice it will go 5, 6, 7 because it will 
follow rules like gravity, momentum, force, and the initial position of the 
dice. So its not random, even in computers, how do you think random its 
calculated ? we need to use factors like date, position and other 
parameters that you will put into calculations and will throw a number, the 
number just doesn't appear magically from nowhere, we make it look like 
that.

Choose another path, choose love instead of fear, happiness instead of 
pain, choose another life, if the world around you is bad, change the 
world, but first, you need to start from yourself. LOVE YOURSELF and you 
will see change.

To This Day
When I was a kid
I used to think that pork chops and karate chops
were the same thing
I thought they were both pork chops
and because my grandmother thought it was cute
and because they were my favourite
she let me keep doing it

not really a big deal

one day
before I realized fat kids are not designed to climb trees
I fell out of a tree
and bruised the right side of my body

I didn’t want to tell my grandmother about it
because I was afraid I’d get in trouble
for playing somewhere that I shouldn’t have been

a few days later the gym teacher noticed the bruise
and I got sent to the principal’s office
from there I was sent to another small room
with a really nice lady
who asked me all kinds of questions
about my life at home

I saw no reason to lie
as far as I was concerned
life was pretty good
I told her “whenever I’m sad
my grandmother gives me karate chops”

this led to a full scale investigation
and I was removed from the house for three days
until they finally decided to ask how I got the bruises

news of this silly little story quickly spread through the school
and I earned my first nickname

pork chop

to this day
I hate pork chops

I’m not the only kid
who grew up this way
surrounded by people who used to say
that rhyme about sticks and stones
as if broken bones
hurt more than the names we got called
and we got called them all
so we grew up believing no one
would ever fall in love with us
that we’d be lonely forever
that we’d never meet someone
to make us feel like the sun
was something they built for us
in their tool shed
so broken heart strings bled the blues
as we tried to empty ourselves
so we would feel nothing
don’t tell me that hurts less than a broken bone
that an ingrown life
is something surgeons can cut away
that there’s no way for it to metastasize

it does

she was eight years old
our first day of grade three
when she got called ugly
we both got moved to the back of the class
so we would stop get bombarded by spit balls
but the school halls were a battleground
where we found ourselves outnumbered day after wretched day
we used to stay inside for recess
because outside was worse
outside we’d have to rehearse running away
or learn to stay still like statues giving no clues that we were there
in grade five they taped a sign to her desk
that read beware of dog

to this day
despite a loving husband
she doesn’t think she’s beautiful
because of a birthmark
that takes up a little less than half of her face
kids used to say she looks like a wrong answer
that someone tried to erase
but couldn’t quite get the job done
and they’ll never understand
that she’s raising two kids
whose definition of beauty
begins with the word mom
because they see her heart
before they see her skin
that she’s only ever always been amazing

he
was a broken branch
grafted onto a different family tree
adopted
but not because his parents opted for a different destiny
he was three when he became a mixed drink
of one part left alone
and two parts tragedy
started therapy in 8th grade
had a personality made up of tests and pills
lived like the uphills were mountains
and the downhills were cliffs
four fifths suicidal
a tidal wave of anti depressants
and an adolescence of being called popper
one part because of the pills
and ninety nine parts because of the cruelty
he tried to kill himself in grade ten
when a kid who still had his mom and dad
had the audacity to tell him “get over it” as if depression
is something that can be remedied
by any of the contents found in a first aid kit

to this day
he is a stick on TNT lit from both ends
could describe to you in detail the way the sky bends
in the moments before it’s about to fall
and despite an army of friends
who all call him an inspiration
he remains a conversation piece between people
who can’t understand
sometimes becoming drug free
has less to do with addiction
and more to do with sanity

we weren’t the only kids who grew up this way
to this day
kids are still being called names
the classics were
hey stupid
hey spaz
seems like each school has an arsenal of names
getting updated every year
and if a kid breaks in a school
and no one around chooses to hear
do they make a sound?
are they just the background noise
of a soundtrack stuck on repeat
when people say things like
kids can be cruel?
every school was a big top circus tent
and the pecking order went
from acrobats to lion tamers
from clowns to carnies
all of these were miles ahead of who we were
we were freaks
lobster claw boys and bearded ladies
oddities
juggling depression and loneliness playing solitaire spin the bottle
trying to kiss the wounded parts of ourselves and heal
but at night
while the others slept
we kept walking the tightrope
it was practice
and yeah
some of us fell

but I want to tell them
that all of this shit
is just debris
leftover when we finally decide to smash all the things we thought
we used to be
and if you can’t see anything beautiful about yourself
get a better mirror
look a little closer
stare a little longer
because there’s something inside you
that made you keep trying
despite everyone who told you to quit
you built a cast around your broken heart
and signed it yourself
you signed it
“they were wrong”
because maybe you didn’t belong to a group or a click
maybe they decided to pick you last for basketball or everything
maybe you used to bring bruises and broken teeth
to show and tell but never told
because how can you hold your ground
if everyone around you wants to bury you beneath it
you have to believe that they were wrong

they have to be wrong

why else would we still be here?
we grew up learning to cheer on the underdog
because we see ourselves in them
we stem from a root planted in the belief
that we are not what we were called we are not abandoned cars stalled out 
and sitting empty on a highway
and if in some way we are
don’t worry
we only got out to walk and get gas
we are graduating members from the class of
fuck off we made it
not the faded echoes of voices crying out
names will never hurt me

of course
they did

but our lives will only ever always
continue to be
a balancing act
that has less to do with pain
and more to do with beauty.﻿

comments.text:
I'm in the same situation. My family is in many ways better than most 
others, I'm loved, have no serious health issues, I'm not bullied and my 
financial situation is pretty good for a student. Still I have a 
semi-severe depression. 
It's a disease, so there's nothing wrong with you personally. Depression 
often have a trigger point, but it's not always obvious and can seemingly 
come from out of the blue. I've had it twice, with a two-year break 
inbetween. First time it was probably caused by my undiagnosed Aspergers, 
since it got better after I was diagnosed. Second time it was the death of 
my dog and my cat having to move away.
Intelligent and creative people are more likely to get depressed because 
their minds require more stimulation to remain healthy. If the mind doesn't 
get enough, it can lead to depression. 
Maybe you can try to change a few things up a bit in your life. Even if 
it's difficult and you might not feel like you have the energy, I'd advice 
you to try. Or try finding brain-teasing games on your level. And take 
small steps outside your comfort zone. It could help.

physical thing. Why do you think people take pills? Because it has

produce feel good chemicals. But there's also a difference between feeling 
"depressed" and being depressed.

top_comment.text:
My Story 🔫-

It started back in kindergarten. I walked into the room and the kids stared 
at me like I was an alien. I went on like I was supposed to. But it wasn't 
easy. First the names, then the abuse, violence. It continued all 
throughout my primary school years. That kid with the glasses. The freak. 
The weirdo nerd. That's all I ever was to them. Reached high school 
expecting it to change but it was only just beginning. Battling through my 
adolescence with nothing but a fake smile and a knife, I was just a 
depressed 13 year old. Suicide attempts made its way onto the picture. Day 
after horrible day, it was always the same. Until I found a way. A way to 
leave it all behind. Through music and dance. I stuck to my passion, made 
it my goal to be who I want to be and be my best. And to this day, I've 
never felt so more eager to live.﻿

Down the hall I stride
My head hanging low
Hair covering my face
The face no one knows

I don't understand 
What's so funny about what they see
I stride faster down the hall
Tears now in my eyes

I stand up strong and tall
And out the door I glide
I walk away with my chin up
And down the hall I stride﻿

top_comment.text:
I could comment positively. I could comment about how this is beautiful. I 
could comment the level of inspiration this is capable of creating. I could 
comment the strength of his words, the accuracy of his message, or any of 
that. But I will not. Instead, just like Shane, I will comment the nasty 
truth that needs to be said: Hypocrisy. That rank filth that seeps into 
everyday life without individuals being aware that they, themselves, are 
part of it. Or knowing they are and being too apathetic to be bothered by 
it. I could comment about how I agree with this, but what would that 
accomplish? Mindless, forgotten, typical Youtube "me too" comment. No. 
Hypocrisy. How many people have seen this and are moved by it, whether they 
commented about it or not, and yet are actually part of the pain this video 
talks about? How many people see this, think "I agree so much with this", 
and yet will go their entire lives blissfully unaware that they have 
demonized others the same way the examples in the video were treated? 
People think they are so innocent - pleasantly ignorant to the pain and 
suffering they dont know they caused or aided in creating. How many 
heartless, depraved, sickening, nauseating wretches believing they are pure 
and innocent? Or that they havent caused enough pain to be worth 
considering? How many people either too incompetent or apathetic enough to 
know or care about the suffering they caused? I challenge you to drop your 
pride and think. Not about what you want to be true or what you think to be 
true. Not about your delusions, your desires, or your ideals. Think about 
this: What DONT you know? What have you likely never considered because it 
was too risky to imagine your fault? Who have you hurt without ever 
realizing it or giving it a second thought? Dont reply to this. Dont deny, 
admit, agree, or disagree. In your own mind, consider the things you havent 
before. Consider the very real possibility that you have aided in, or 
caused, the suffering of another and have been blissfully unaware of it. 
For those of you whom may have trouble doing so: Think about YOUR pain. 
Think about what YOU have been forced to endure. Think about YOUR troubles, 
YOUR struggles, YOUR suffering. Think about the people that caused that. 
Think about the reason those things - those feelings - happened. Imagine 
those people who hurt you went their entire lives never being aware they 
did it, or not caring that they did even if they knew they hurt you. 
Imagine those people being unaware of the pain they put you through, then 
ask yourself "What if that is how somebody else sees me?"﻿

comments.text:
+Emilio The Derpy Killer  Let me tell you something...I don't care if you 
are fat, I don't care if you was mentally disabled, I don't care if you was 
called names because of how you looked, how you dressed, how you talked, 
how you walked, how you done anything through your life...because i had 
gone through the same thing and it hurts me too see others like you in this 
type of situation and i can't do nothing about it...
When i was in kindergarten i didn't care about anything.I was outgoing, i 
was optimistic i had great views of the world.I mostly viewed the world in 
color, in fact i was so optimistic if you see a car accident, or any 
accident in particular...you would see me still smiling seeing that someone 
still got out alive saying thank god someone got out crying...until i had 
hit 3rd grade...i had done too many things that i would regret during that 
point in time i don't even want to remember it...People then called me a 
loser, then they made fun of how i looked...they made fun of me because of 
how i ran awkwardly...i was mocked for being "different" towards them...I 
was made fun of for years to come, even today i cant even look at my 
friends without feeling distrust or feeling like they don't even like me 
around them...You know the same car accident i had just mentioned...instead 
of me saying thank god and crying...I would say nothing with a stotic face 
and just walk away like nothing happened...i wouldn't even care who was 
part of it i would just say nothing and just walk away...
I felt terrible for over 5~7 years and i feel depressed over how bad my 
life was and how i treated it, and how insignificant my life was towards 
everyone around me...now im practically the laughing stalk for anyone who 
would have done so like it...I later on i had gotten tired of my endless 
stream of punishment so...i had tried committing suicide...Twice in my 
lifetime...Once when i was 8, and one time during last month...but...i had 
stopped trying to do so... What made me stop before i had done so was only 
one thing...how would my parents feel, how would my family felt...if i had 
disappeared...and i will never come back...that made me feel terrible 
because their lives was crushed because of my own selfishness to rid of my 
own problems...so i had stopped myself from making that killing thrust that 
could've ended my life...
So that is why i care so much about people like you because people like you 
are great people to talk too and i enjoy your company...
IK it was a bit of a mouthful...but i wanted to shave that off my chest 
while i still had it in mind...if you want you can tell this to others 
about my story...relive my stress a bit...go ahead...

comments.text:
Hey girl. Or dude. Hang on tight. Hang on to that life of yours, with 
everything you have, even if it's by a thread. I was the same grade as you, 
grade 7, when I made these same attempts on my life, and felt the same way. 
The scars I have from over the years remind me of a much more difficult 
battle than I've ever known any of my peers to go through. Depression 
is...a curse. But it's a curse that makes you wiser and more powerful than 
you can ever imagine. People who do not understand will not see you for who 
you are, but those who matter do...and the true you is indestructible, and 
immeasurably beautiful. Who cares about a bit of extra chunk, or looks that 
don't meet society's standards? Only common kids in middle school. You are 
still here, and there is a reason for that. There's something remarkable 
about you that sets you apart from the rest. And you will NOT BE ALONE. 
When someone sees you for you, they will love you relentlessly. Just do me 
a favor, and last one year...then pick a high school where you feel 
comfortable. Somewhere with aligned interests, and feels open and 
welcoming. Don't give up until you've found somewhere you belong. That's 
what I decided, ten years ago....now I am 21 and still very much alive, 
something I never would have expected. I live with scars, but...well, I've 
been told it makes me into a bit of a badass. ;) Take care.
comments.author: flutesandswords

I was bullied. It affected me so much because I didn't know what to do, 
where to go. I have a house and a family but everytime I went home from 
school I still felt alone. I was awake but I was also in a bad dream. 
Always. All I wanted was to be myself without anyone ridiculing me for it. 
Up until now, even though it was 6 years ago, that nightmare still haunts 
me. But I had to do something. I had to stop being weak. So the next year, 
I became the bully. I enjoyed making fun of others and their weaknesses. I 
was callous. I was proud. But I finally made it. People finally respected 
me. But the down part of it is that a lot of people also hated me. And I 
got into a lot of trouble. Lost a lot of friends in the end. Karma. Guys, 
it's an ugly cycle. ﻿

top_comment.text:
I'm not a sort of person that cries because of something I see. This is one 
of the first videos that have legitimately brought me to tears.

I have been bullied before, ever since I stepped foot into that hellhole 
called elementary school. I never told my parents about it, and when I did, 
I didn't say much. Becuase I didn't want to be known as the snitch or the 
weakling.
I've always been one of those people in those special programs for the 
smart kids (although i don't see myself as smart), and this brought on 
eight years of being bullied because of it. Getting beat up, called names 
like "dumbass" or "smartass", getting rocks thrown at me, ect. I lost 
friends, because people didn't want to be around that girl that was getting 
teased or tricked all the time. There's still much more on that list, but I 
continued to live like nothing was going on, because I had always kept a 
shred of hope that things would get better, like they do in all of those 
draw my life type of stories.
Continued to lose friends, more bullying.
Parents got divorced, more bullying.
Grandfather died, more bullying.
My sister became a force to be reckoned with halfway through university. 
MORE FUCKING BULLYING.

To this day, things are still going downhill, and every day, I start to 
lose a little bit of that hope that there actually is an uphill. ﻿

I am sorry @ItsMaddy. I understand your pain, not from being a receiver of 
the brutality and bullying but as a protector of those being bullied. I was 
always taught by my Mom and Dad that everyone was unique and I should learn 
to love them and protect them. Many times I got into fights simply because 
someone was being pushed around and I stepped in for the person being beat 
on. Several times I didn't even know the people I was standing up for and 
even though I would get cuts and bruises, atleast I knew that I was making 
someone's life better. I often became friends with them and they would 
always ask me why I helped them. It was a simple answer. I cared about them.
It does get better. Every single one of them agree with that statement. I 
am sorry someone like me wasn't there to help you. I wish I was. Nothing 
makes me sadder than hearing about amazing people like you. Someone who 
should be celebrated. Someone who should be loved. Not kicked around. 
You're life WILL get better. While the hill you are on is steep, while 
every step gets heavier, While it may seem like you will not get to the 
top. You will come to a day where you finally feel all that weight lifted. 
My friend once told me, Life is full of evil, but it is also filled with 
good. We all encounter evil, but we also all encounter good. A primitive 
saying but it got him through it all. 
I came close to tears numerous times while watching this because all those 
years where I helped people in your position. I never would have guessed 
how impactful this video would have been when I first looked at it. And now 
that I think of it, I learned about this video from a friend of mine who is 
14, gay, atheist and also a native american in a very religious, racist 
white populated area.He sent me this video and told me that he was thankful 
that I was there to help him through his first year of High school. I was 
not in high school of course, but I was friendly to him, I made him feel 
like he was wanted. He said that without me, he would have possibly 
committed suicide. I only bring this up because it will apply to you. Some 
day you will find someone who makes you feel safe. Someone that will 
shelter you from the evil of this world because you deserve it. Everyone 
who this post applies to deserves that. This will get better everyone. I 
promise.

comments.text:
I find it sad when a bully is bullied by the victim in a similar manner to 
the bully bullies the victim, for vengeance. People seem to forget the 
reason people actually resort to bullying: they, too, were probably victims 
themselves. They make their insecurities as apparent as a derogatory term 
to others' faces, from a punch, to a kick, to the whines to the heavens. 

It is not always about the victim of typical occurrence that must be taken 
into consideration: the bully is at more fault for appropriate reason, but 
they are hurting themselves far more subtly. They might not even be aware 
that they themselves are actually becoming a bully: I did not know since my 
vision, hearing, smell, taste, coordination, memory, and other mental 
abilities were deteriorating at a horrifying rate.

Now I know that my justifiable fear for others and hurting others because 
of my own mistakes was only holding me back in the same way that I never 
let go of my regrets. I managed to self-rehabilitate myself to the point 
where I am now better person inside and out, even though I've always lived 
by my moral code.

+supermegazeldaland You said it yourself but It doesn't make you  inferior. 
In some areas yes, it would. But as you said, it causes you to excel in 
other areas. Look at Hawking, he can not move a muscle in his body and is 
one of the greatest scientists of our time. Triumph through adversity. I'm 
sure you are a stronger individual than I.
Now, to shut up that goddamn voice, this will sound silly, but it works. 
It's a devil, a little fucker intent on bringing you down. It gains 
pleasure from your misery and there are lots of different types. Whichever 
one grabs you, visualise it, however you like. An oppressive cloud around 
your head, a sad skeleton on your back, visualise it. Then, grab it, push 
it,, blow it, seal it away, then, importantly, get on with the task at 
hand. It will come back eventually, but it can't beat you physically, just 
drain you mentally. Kill the fucker again and again. There are lots of 
different kinds, self doubt is the worst  and easiest to kill. This works 
because the doubt is in your head you can kill it there too. Good luck.

comments.text:
You are not alone. Trust me. All my life i have felt like you. And it only 
got worse when i saw friends or family members finding people to spend 
their life with. I'm trying to "Fix" myself but after all this time i know 
i can't be fixed. I can only tell you that you are certainly NOT alone. I'm 
not saying to get over it or anything. I'm saying there are people who know 
how it feels. And i'm not talking about doctors,psychiatrists or 
psychologists. People who are in the same situation as you. I'm not telling 
you to find help or "Get better". Fuck people who tell you that. Try to 
focus on things you love and if you have friends hang out with them and 
distract that little voice in your head. It's the only way i'm able to keep 
part of my sanity.

Take care and remember: You are NOT alone.

comments.text:
I will tell you this right now. I don't care what you look like, I don't 
care what others have told you, I don't care how you have been treated, 
where you came from, the color of your skin, the cloths you wear, the 
grades you get or any of the other crap people use to put you down. Because 
those things don't matter. All that matters is that you are a human being. 
And a human being is beautiful. I can say it right now. You are beautiful. 
Everyone is. Some people might try to push you down. To tell you that you 
are nothing, and that they own you. Don't listen to them. Because listening 
to them makes then right. If you let them, they will own you. All you have 
to do is tell someone. Anyone. If that doesn't work, tell someone else, and 
keep going until you get the leader of whatever country you live in. 
Because at some point, some where, there will be someone who will listen. 
Someone who will help. Until then, remember this. How can something be 
beautiful, if beauty is subjective? Because true beauty is created from 
your character. Not your looks, not your cloths, not your family, not any 
of those things. 

Don't let the world drag you down with it. Because the world isn't going to 
a fun place. Its going to Hell.

comments.text:
But...
You are a human being.
On one hand a flawed monkey that cannot control it's emotions.
On the other: 
You are the closest Earth has ever seen to both physical and mental 
perfection. You are a biological machine complex enough to assign meaning 
to a difference in electromagnetic oscillations accurate to under 100 
nano-meters; not just in a mechanical fashion but in such a way as to 
assign unique emotional meaning with no discreet measurement. Were you to 
train yourself you have the ability to predict the motion of the heavens 
themselves. You are absolutely awesome, don't forget that. So don't say you 
are fucking worthless, you are amazing and possess infinite potential. I 
can't say don't be sad, because that's useless. Instead surround yourself 
in people who acknowledge the fantastic nature of humanity and your 
inherent value as not just a human but a person. A person that provides a 
unique perspective in both outlook and beauty. 
Please.

comments.text:
What you don't seem to understand is that not everyone has the guts to do 
so. I'm 19, but I was bullied EVERY. DAY. of school when I was 12-13, they 
told me I was ugly, gave me names. Every day. I was so shy and felt so 
intimidated it only made it worse. I was in the middle of puberty and it's 
usually not a moment when you feel confident about yourself and your body 
and everything, and I was younger than everyone else because I had skipped 
one grade in the past. I had no one I could tell about it. I tried to tell 
my parents, they told me I exaggerated or that I should get over it because 
it happens to everyone in school. That's not true. I was a real scapegoat 
for my class. I would have told my teachers, but either they CHOSE not to 
see it, or they went along with my bullies (it happened for real). I even 
had a fight with some girls. It depends on your personality, I was just to 
shy, too afraid and too young to realize that what I was going through was 
not normal. I feared that if I told something it would make things worse. 
So I hid, made myself as invisible as possible, and waited.

I took me many years to open up again and regain confidence. Of course if 
this had happened to me when I was a little older, I would have handled the 
situation differently, I would have spoken up, tried to defend myself. I'm 
not who I was back then. Probably these events made me who I am today. But 
today, I'm a grown up, I'm not alone, I have friends and passions besides 
school and things that keep me going. Bullying does not make you stronger, 
it destroys you on the inside, and it takes a lot of time to heal.

I'm not complaining, I just want you to understand that not everyone is 
like you. And every situation is different.

top_comment.text:
http://youtu.be/ltun92DfnPY
When I was a kid
I used to think that pork chops and karate chops
Were the same thing
I thought they were both pork chops
And because my grandmother thought it was cute
And because they were my favourite
She let me keep doing it

Not really a big deal

One day
Before I realized fat kids are not designed to climb trees
I fell out of a tree
And bruised the right side of my body

I didn’t want to tell my grandmother about it
Because I was afraid I’d get in trouble
For playing somewhere that I shouldn’t have been

A few days later the gym teacher noticed the bruise
And I got sent to the principal’s office
From there I was sent to another small room
With a really nice lady
Who asked me all kinds of questions
About my life at home

I saw no reason to lie
As far as I was concerned
Life was pretty good
I told her, “Whenever I’m sad
My grandmother gives me karate chops”

This led to a full scale investigation
And I was removed from the house for three days
Until they finally decided to ask how I got the bruises

News of this silly little story quickly spread through the school
And I earned my first nickname

Pork Chop

To this day
I hate pork chops

I’m not the only kid
Who grew up this way
Surrounded by people who used to say
That rhyme about sticks and stones
As if broken bones
Hurt more than the names we got called
And we got called them all
So we grew up believing no one
Would ever fall in love with us
That we’d be lonely forever
That we’d never meet someone
To make us feel like the sun
Was something they built for us
In their tool shed
So broken heart strings bled the blues
As we tried to empty ourselves
So we would feel nothing
Don’t tell me that hurts less than a broken bone
That an ingrown life
Is something surgeons can cut away
That there’s no way for it to metastasize

It does

She was eight years old
Our first day of grade three
When she got called ugly
We both got moved to the back of the class
So we would stop get bombarded by spit balls
But the school halls were a battleground
Where we found ourselves outnumbered day after wretched day
We used to stay inside for recess
Because outside was worse
Outside we’d have to rehearse running away
Or learn to stay still like statues giving no clues that we were there
In grade five they taped a sign to her desk
That read beware of dog

To this day
Despite a loving husband
She doesn’t think she’s beautiful
Because of a birthmark
That takes up a little less than half of her face
Kids used to say she looks like a wrong answer
That someone tried to erase
But couldn’t quite get the job done
And they’ll never understand
That she’s raising two kids
Whose definition of beauty
Begins with the word mom
Because they see her heart
Before they see her skin
Because she’s only ever always been amazing

He
Was a broken branch
Grafted onto a different family tree
Adopted
Not because his parents opted for a different destiny
He was three when he became a mixed drink
Of one part left alone
And two parts tragedy
Started therapy in 8th grade
Had a personality made up of tests and pills
Lived like the uphills were mountains
And the downhills were cliffs
Four fifths suicidal
A tidal wave of anti depressants
And an adolescence of being called popper
One part because of the pills
Ninety nine parts because of the cruelty
He tried to kill himself in grade ten
When a kid who could still go home to mom and dad
Had the audacity to tell him “get over it” as if depression
Is something that can be remedied
By any of the contents found in a first aid kit

To this day
He is a stick of TNT lit from both ends
Could describe to you in detail the way the sky bends
In the moments before it’s about to fall
And despite an army of friends
Who all call him an inspiration
He remains a conversation piece between people
Who can’t understand
Sometimes becoming drug free
Has less to do with addiction
And more to do with sanity

We weren’t the only kids who grew up this way
To this day
Kids are still being called names
The classics were
Hey stupid
Hey spaz
Seems like each school has an arsenal of names
Getting updated every year
And if a kid breaks in a school
And no one around chooses to hear
Do they make a sound?
Are they just the background noise
Of a soundtrack stuck on repeat
When people say things like
Kids can be cruel?
Every school was a big top circus tent
And the pecking order went
From acrobats to lion tamers
From clowns to carnies
All of these were miles ahead of who we were
We were freaks
Lobster claw boys and bearded ladies
Oddities
Juggling depression and loneliness playing solitaire spin the bottle
Trying to kiss the wounded parts of ourselves and heal
But at night
While the others slept
We kept walking the tightrope
It was practice
And yes
Some of us fell

But I want to tell them
That all of this
Is just debris
Leftover when we finally decide to smash all the things we thought
We used to be
And if you can’t see anything beautiful about yourself
Get a better mirror
Look a little closer
Stare a little longer
Because there’s something inside you
That made you keep trying
Despite everyone who told you to quit
You built a cast around your broken heart
And signed it yourself
You signed it
“They were wrong”
Because maybe you didn’t belong to a group or a clique
Maybe they decided to pick you last for basketball or everything
Maybe you used to bring bruises and broken teeth
To show and tell but never told
Because how can you hold your ground
If everyone around you wants to bury you beneath it
You have to believe that they were wrong

They have to be wrong

Why else would we still be here?
We grew up learning to cheer on the underdog
Because we see ourselves in them
We stem from a root planted in the belief
That we are not what we were called
We are not abandoned cars stalled out and
Sitting empty on a highway
And if in some way we are
Don’t worry
We only got out to walk and get gas
We are graduating members from the class of We Made It
Not the faded echoes of voices crying out
Names will never hurt me

Of course
They did

But our lives will only ever always
Continue to be
A balancing act
That has less to do with pain
And more to do with beauty
-Shane Koyzcan﻿

comments.text:
You might only do it once to that person.
But you won't be the only one taking part.  You won't be the only one with 
something to say.  You might be the first, but you won't be the last, and 
you won't be blameless.

As someone who had to deal with bullying from my entire school, for seven 
years of my life, I can tell you that the person who only called me a name 
once or twice, is no less responsible than the person who ridiculed me day 
to day.
I had a harder time dealing with the one-offs.  With the passing comments. 
 With the person I didn't even know, but who seemed to know me, and who was 
in on the joke.
In fact, those are the ones that really hurt.

You build up a thick skin around certain people.  After years, you expect 
it from some of the kids.  But when the kid you don't know laughs and calls 
you a name in the hall, it hurts hardest. 

What I'm saying is that what you're doing isn't harmless.  It isn't all fun 
and games.  It's damaging.

top_comment.text:
I used to get bullied at gymnastics. So much that I quit, I couldn't stand 
the hate and I didn't understand what they thought was wrong with me. So 
what, I wasn't that flexible, I could still be great, but they shunned me 
and ignored me. I thought if could be friends with them, then maybe they'd 
understand. But they didn't and I walked away from a dream. They don't 
realise this, but I can't watch parts of the Summer and Winter Olympics. I 
can't watch gymnastics in the summer and figure skating in winter. It 
reminds me of what I could have been, and what I gave up on. 

Just so people know I have moved on. I wasn't flexible because I was 
muscular. I used my muscles and became an athlete. Soccer, basketball, 
track, swimming, and snowboarding. I used my inflexibility to realise that 
I didn't care about being flexible any more. I cared about sports, it gave 
me friends. I wasn't the girl who took gymnastics anymore.

This all seems incredibly happy, it isn't. I was still bullied, bullied for 
my "fat legs". I was bullied because I got over one thing, moved on, and 
then became to comfortable. I was getting to muscular. The one thing I 
embraced about myself was getting me into trouble. 

For everyone getting bullied, I found a release in sports, you find your 
release. Then, grow your wings and take off. I have huge legs, but their 
muscular and I'm a star, I found my release and never looked back.
﻿

+ItsMeRivy
Yes Rivy!  Depression is indeed real, as is anxiety and a number of other 
human conditions. However, for far too long now they have been grossly 
misunderstood and as such, those whose attention have been directed by it, 
are regarded as having no social value, when in history demonstrates that 
the opposite is true beyond debate.

Historically, depression (specifically) has been the sole driver of 
scientific discovery, technological revolutions and critical paradigms 
shifts in social values leading to the greatest social revolutions 
throughout each generation.

So, although it can be the most burdensome thing one could possibly imagine 
enduring,.try to imagine life without it.  Depression is for the strong not 
the weak.

I hope you find these words encouraging.

I do agree with you on alot of what you said. If someones gonna clain 
suicide, if theyre really that fucked, yeah I think they should just do it 
otherwise I think they just want attention. & im not gonna lie, I used to 
be one of the weak ones. I used to cut because i spent so much time feeling 
sorry for myself. I was playing the victim. & I think bullying is taken yo 
harshly. You cant criticize anyone without being a bully. I think bullying 
can be a good thing tbh because as sad as it is thats how it is in the real 
world & if youre taught at a young age to be fucking ruthless you will 
survive. Its all about survival of the fittest. But I do think its unfair 
to say depression is only a figment of imagination. I think for alot of 
people it is. Not every teenager now in days can be chemically depressed. 
But it is a chemical imbalance in the brain. Chemicak depression is when 
you lack Serotonin, which is a nuerotransmitter that effects a ton of 
things within you. Your mood, your perceptiob on pain, even body movements 
like twitches & tremours. So though I agree with you on alot of what you 
said it is unfair to say all depression is psychological. Alot of it is, 
but not all of it.

comments.text:
generally people associate drugs with addiction, and when somoene is drug 
free we think of someone who just got out of rehab and is off of drugs, 
they beat the issue. But this is talking about anti-depressant medication, 
which can help treat someone with depression and anxiety, and eventually 
people who take this (such as myself) come off of it over the years, 
because they have gained their sanity and have been near treated. So it's 
saying people who are drug free aren't always someone who was addicted and 
off of drugs, but someone who was broken in the mind and mended themselves.

comments.text:
i don't know if this will help but when i was your age i was in a very 
similar situation. i had practically no friends, was bullied daily by a lot 
of different people (a lot of whom i didn't even know), rumours were 
spread, names were called, people would follow me around antagonising me 
and threatening me, they'd walk past my house and shout things over the 
hedge if they could see i was in my back garden, they'd do all kinds of 
horrible shit to me, like spit at me, try to ice me out rooms, gang up on 
me, throw things at me the list goes on. i felt so heartbroken and so alone 
there was a lot of other things going on in my life at that time to and i 
was hurting really badly, i felt ugly and disgusting and genuinely started 
to believe i deserved to be treated like that like it was somehow my fault. 
it was horrible i felt so ugly that i couldn't look at the refletion of my 
face without feeling physically ill because i was so disgusted by it. but 
it didn't last. i got through it. i eventually found some genuine people 
who were amazing and cared about me, who helped me pull myself out of the 
darkness and i started to realise i wasn't so alone that i have a family 
that loves me, that i had friends i didn't even know i had and that i'm 
generally awesome lol. it's hard i'm 22 years old now and i still struggle, 
it's hard dealing with and recovering from living life like that, it's so 
difficult i can't properly describe it with words but i can look in the 
mirror now and rather than feeling sick i really like the face that's 
looking back at me and it makes me smile. if there's something stopping you 
from making friends trust me it's their problem not yours i learnt that the 
hard way, be your own friend if you have to for now, be open to making 
friends but try not to think about it too much if they can't see how 
incredible you are then they aren't worth your time. the heartache is 
excruciating but you can survive it, it sounds cheesy but it does 
definitely get better but only if you stay strong, keep your head high and 
remind yourself every single day how amazing you are. (start of small find 
one thing about yourself and focus on that then find something else the 
next day etc. it's silly but it helps).

comments.text:
You know what I like about you? After your first comment, all of your 
replies don't sound like you're afraid. You wanna hear a story? Private 
school. There's one thing the teachers at mine knew: if a kid does 
something you don't like, punish them. These were normally just scoldings, 
but the thing is, if it happens more often than most, other kids will just 
look down on you. More than once, I was called idiot, stupid, and one time, 
the b word, when absolutely no one was looking. A few kids did it more 
often than most, and one also like throwing me around once in a while. And 
do you know the worst part? It broke me. After the longest time, I started 
treating my brother like that. Sometimes, I still do, out of instinct. It's 
enough to make me hate myself. Switching to public school? It felt worse at 
the time. Thousands of cuss words and swears flying all around me, 
sometimes directed at me, when I didn't realize that they were trying to be 
friendly. Those dirty jokes were what they were used to. They all laughed 
at each other about it. But when they tried talking to me, I assumed the 
worst. I was broken, and kept breaking myself into smaller pieces. Trust 
me, you're stronger.
comments.author: Martin Johnson

comments.text:
I was born with a birthmark on one side of my face and didn't have many 
friends when I was your age either. I find that kids are generally meaner 
than adults….I feel they are more shallow and more easily say nasty things 
about other people. This isn't always the case and of course but I think 
just on average kids are more openly mean to others. I feel teens are "on 
average" also more shallow about physical looks than people who are a bit 
older. Plus a lot of other teens are struggling with their own identity 
crisis in some way, and are more likely to lash out and put someone else 
down.

When people call someone ugly I don't even know if they always actually 
mean that or if it's just an easy thing to say to make someone feel bad. 
Some people just want to put someone down so they will say mean things even 
if that's not truly what they believe.

Anyway, at your age you're also still growing. You might look quite 
different a few years from now. Either way though, I don't think anyone 
looks ugly. I don't find everyone in the world attractive but who does? 
When someone isn't attractive to me personally though, I don't see them as 
ugly. I just see them as not my type. It doesn't make them ugly. Someone 
else would probably find them attractive.

Somebody please respond. I'm so close to the edge and I don't know how long 
I can bottle my feelings. I was born premature. For the first year of my 
life, my family thought I wasn't going to make it because had to go to the 
hospital daily. When I was 5, I started school. I was quiet, and these kids 
used to bully me because I stuttered. They'd say I stutter because I was 
never supposed to be born, and god didn't want me to tainte anybody's minds 
so he stopped me from talking so clearly. By age six I believed if I died 
it would be okay, because my family and friends would move on. Now, at 15, 
I don't think of myself as pretty. My friends say I weigh "5 pounds" 
because I was born premature and I'm very small. My friends say I'm ugly 
even when I'm a model. My friends call me stupid and worthless because of 
my ADHD. My parents and siblings think I have problems because I lock 
myself in my room. They think I'm depressed, and they're right. My 
boyfriend dumped me for the girl who tells me I'm worthless and claims to 
be my friend.  I say "like" and click my tongue to stop myself from 
stuttering, and people make fun of it. I try to be nice and outgoing but 
people think I'm annoying. My IQ is well over the american female average. 
I have A's in all of my classes, but I feel like I'm worthless. I tell my 
friends that I'm sad and they say that have way bigger problems and mine 
aren't  valid because they're "going through worse". Today my older sister 
told me I was a mistake, and I need to go to a mental ward. My mom said I 
have problems. My friends said I'm "too pretty and skinny to be depressed". 
My friend said she could kick my ass and I'm as strong as a 2 year old, 
even though I practice Muay Thai and have mastered lots of moves. My 
friends said I have "no butt" and I'm "as flat as Taylor Swift" because I 
weight 100ish pounds at 15. That's not my fault, I like to excersise and 
I'm just not hungry every 10 minutes. Today a boy said my nose, which I 
broke and can't afford the plastic surgery to make my nose perfect again, 
looks like a penis and I'm pinocchio, and my friend liked the comment. ﻿

comments.text:
I believe that the people who are pushing you to your breaking point are 
all wrong. Sure, you have some flaws that can not be reversed, but you 
shouldn't let those things take over your emotions. Prove them wrong that 
you are capable of doing more than just what they think u can do. & who 
cares if you are different from everyone else? In the long run, the only 
thing that matters is for you to know that you are healthy & well. Being a 
teen is tough, considering I am one. Never lose track of the bright side of 
everything. Even though i dont know you, I can tell that all u need is 
someone to talk to you. U might already do have someone to talk to but you 
know what, the more, the better. Don't let anyone dull your sparkle because 
you are going to be the best version of you you will ever be once you learn 
that deep down inside your mind, you are just a freaking amazing person & 
that u deserve the world. Be the person you truly want to be. :)

comments.text:
I know I am a bit late to reply to this comment, but I have been through 
bullying myself. Those 'Friends' you have shouldn't be in your life if they 
are going to treat you that way. Because let me tell you something. I may 
have never EVER met you before, but I know you are perfect, even if you 
have flaws, you are perfect. Not being skinny or pretty make you perfect, 
but being real and staying true to who you know you are, deep inside. A 
happy person, who is capable of shutting all those mean things out, not 
letting them bother you. And let me tell you something else. If your 
boyfriend dumped you for one of your bullies, then he isn't worth being 
upset over. One day, you will find a guy who loves every. single. thing. 
about you, and you will feel the same way. And some day, you will have 
friends who are really more of your brothers and sisters than friends, and 
who would sacrifice their own lives for you. You just have to hang in 
there, and believe it. You have to be patient, but it will happen. You are 
perfect, beautiful, nice, kind, everything about you is amazing, okay? So 
don't you EVER believe them I have lost a few family members to suicide 
because of people making them feel insecure, and its not worth giving up 
your life. And your sister? If she said you were a mistake, she jealous. 
Jealous that you are brave enough to walk through the school halls and LIFE 
everyday. And rightfully so, at that. And if she wants to make you feel 
bad, just let it go. She is your sister, and sisters are also meant to be 
mean, but deep down inside, they love you more than anything. I was 
bullied. Kids chased me in the playground when I was six saying "time to 
take out the trash!" and other things. It got so bad I didn't want to go to 
school, and refused to get ready. Though the years, I have realized 
something. These bullies, they aren't gonna mean a thing to you when your 
older. That your going to go on to do great things, and they won't be there 
to stop you. So just take one thing from this: You are a perfect, beautiful 
human being, even WITH whatever flaws you think you have. 

-Kaitlyn
comments.author: KaitieGames XD

comments.text:
Stay strong and learn to love yourself. People are often very irrational - 
because you sound like a great person who has many interests and always 
tries her best. There are those who hate anyone that is better than them, 
so pay no mind to unjustified opinions. However, never think you're perfect 
- always accept critique and stay humble. Remember that we are social 
creatures. Maybe your friend liked that mean comment because s/he feels 
that will help fit in and that is understandable - sometimes we do get 
caught up in the moment and don't understand how our actions affect others. 
But if this persists,you should get rid of them - realize that people who 
berate you and make you feel bad are NOT your friends.  Don't get down :)

top_comment.text:
This video. I remember watching it a little while ago during an anti 
bullying assembly. I've always been small, small enough that I was never 
able to do anything about being bullied. The names the physical abuse and 
even the flat out intimidation thrown at me from other people was enormous. 
I couldn't help bursting into tears at the end of it and had to skip last 
class so no one thought anything was wrong. The part with the boy always 
being picked last hits me hard because no matter what bullying was the 
worst during gym. It"s always apart of the game but it never really is. 
Whether is was getting slammed into the ground by someone who wanted to 
pass you or getting picked up and tossed into a wall because you didn't 
catch something, it never stopped hurting. Even the words haunt me. Along 
with being small I am quite thin. They called me anorexic starving and bone 
boy, to make matters worse I have dress in mainly black and eat alone 
everyday to the fact that I have no friends. All of these factors came 
together to give me the Nickname Mr. Emo. My bruises and scrapes heal but I 
carry around those words wherever I go. I pour my heart out into everyone I 
meet but no one ever stays long enough to see what I see. Today I even had 
a girl come over to me and say "suck it up bruises heal". Sticks and stones 
may break my fucking bones but the scars words leave last forever. Thanks 
for listening guys sorry if I wasted your time.﻿

comments.text:
+Piotr Monaco You do understand that what your comment was is a blanket 
statement, correct? And that blanket statements work about as well as a 
match in the vacuum of space. Here's an example; all black people call 
their friends "nigga" and hate white people. That's obviously wrong, since 
not every person with African descent does that. The same can be said for 
your little statement. Not everyone is you; everyone you know is different 
from you, and so is everyone they know. People have different emotions and 
different chemical make-ups, meaning that while you're sitting here being 
insensitive and idiotic, someone you hang out with could very well be on 
the verge of suicide or on the verge of murdering their family. Sure, you 
can dismiss that as mental illness, but not everyone is suffering from 
issues because of illness. Plus, illnesses like depression can crop up from 
a variety of reasons and are harder to cure than simply saying "get over 
it."
Also, if you're implying that humans are in any way like other animals, 
you're wrong there as well. We are animals, yes, but we're not like them. 
We're capable of shaping our environment to better suit our needs. 
Therefore, we're all weak. So, by your logic, no human on this planet is 
strong, so none of us deserve to be alive. We depend on other humans and 
technology; remember that. So, when one of us falls over and can't go on, 
you're willing to further weaken an already weak species by killing off 
vital portions of what makes us strong? That makes about as much sense as 
Hitler's hatred for Jews, and is very similar in many ways. You have no 
idea how it feels to be someone with depression, it's quite obvious; you've 
probably got a very good or mediocre home life. Why not go ask your parents 
to start beating you and withholding food from you? Or maybe why not get 
rid of one parent? Or make one of them a drug addict? You'll be tooting a 
different horn then, but why should we listen when you do? You'll be "weak" 
and you'll "deserve to be shot."
I'm just going to be frank with you; you need to open your mind and not be 
a complete douchebag. Your the kind of person who gets shot because of 
something they say. Because you have no experience with depression, or with 
helping prevent someone with depression from committing suicide, you have 
no place talking about it like you're an expert.
Please take any anger or rudeness on my behalf with a grain of salt; I'm 
not angry at you, just at your ignorance. You're most likely an okay person 
to be around. And I also apologize if this comment came off long to you. I 
tend to type a lot.
Good day, and try widening your perspective.
